article_title: The Legal Case Unions Fear They Cannot Win
article_text:
It has been a difficult five years for government-employee unions, and the Supreme Court appears poised to strike another blow. During the current term, the justices will hear Friedrichs v. California Teachers Association, a case challenging rules in 23 states—including California, Illinois and New York—that force government workers to pay hefty “agency fees” to unions that they have no interest in joining.

Labor activists call these “fair share fees,” on the theory that nonunion workers, even if they don’t pay full dues,...

twitter.description: In The Wall Street Journal, Steve Malanga writes about the legal case unions fear they cannot win: Can government workers be forced to pay fees to unions? The Supreme Court seems inclined to say no.
twitter.title: The Legal Case Unions Fear They Cannot Win

It has been a difficult five years for government-employee unions, and the Supreme Court appears poised to strike another blow.
During the current term, the justices will hear Friedrichs v. California Teachers Association, a case challenging rules in 23 states—including California, Illinois and New York—that force government workers to pay hefty “agency fees” to unions that they have no interest in joining.
